I would be extremely hesitant to describe any river as flowing "backwards", given you weren't there to see ths initial state. It changes direction, it does not "flow backwards", which implies there is an innate "forwards", and that simply... never was a thing in the first place. Sometimes rivers change direction, but they're always flowing the direction they should be due to the physics involved. It's always flowing in the correct direction, we just tend to overconceptualise things to the point of literal absurdity. A river flowing "backwards" is meaningless.
Interesting fact about the river's name. Tonle just means River, and Sap means Fresh (Like Fresh Water), so Tonle Sap means Fresh River.
We have something like that in New Brunswick, Canada.  It's called Reversing Falls.  We built a restaurant atop it so one can eat while watching the water slowly change direction.
